newsitem.title: GERMANY: Airports should have say in slot allocation.
newsitem.headline: Airports should have say in slot allocation.

text.p: Airports should be given a bigger say in how slots are allocated to airlines, a top Frankfurt airport (FRA) official said.
Manfred Schoelch, vice-chairman of Flughafen Frankfurt Main AG (FAG), said the EU should take more account of airports in its current considerations on reform of the existing slot allocation system.

"It should recognise that the number of available slots is decisively influenced by airport investment in take-off and landing runway systems," he said in a speech to the 5th Frankfurt Air Travel Symposium at Frankfurt airport.
But he added: "We do not want to put the existing system into question."
In Germany, a national flight co-ordinator is responsible for deciding which airlines should get slots at which airports at which times.
Frankfurt airport plans to increase its number of available slots per hour to 80 in 2000 from 72 in 1996 through runway and air traffic control improvements.
